title: 110_s851
content: The Act titled "Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2007" introduces the Higher Education Opportunity Credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit allows eligible students to claim a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses. The credit amount is 100% of expenses up to $1,000, 50% for expenses between $1,000 and $3,000, and 20% for expenses between $3,000 and $5,500. There are limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit reduces the taxable amount based on modified adjusted gross income. The reduction is calculated as a ratio of the excess income over $70,000 ($140,000 for joint returns) to $20,000 ($40,000 for joint returns). The Higher Education Opportunity Credit limits the credit based on modified adjusted gross income, which is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income increased by certain exclusions. The credit amount cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus certain other taxes, with specific thresholds for income levels. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit limits the credit to 3 eligible students per taxable year, with additional restrictions on the number of years the credit can be claimed for each student. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit limits the credit to 3 eligible students per taxable year, with restrictions on the number of years the credit can be claimed for each student. The credit is not allowed unless the individual is an eligible student for at least one academic period during the year. Additionally, the credit is denied if the student has been convicted of a felony drug offense before the end of the taxable year. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets specific requirements and is carrying at least half of a full-time workload for their course of study. Qualified tuition and related expenses include necessary fees for education. The term 'related expenses' includes tuition, fees, and 50% of book costs for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent enrolled at an eligible educational institution. The amount of tuition and fees considered for tax purposes is limited to $250 per eligible student per year. Expenses related to sports, games, hobbies, nonacademic fees like student activity fees, athletic fees, and insurance expenses are not included. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 defines an eligible educational institution as one described in section 481 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for participation in a program under title IV of the same Act. Taxpayers can choose not to apply this section to qualified tuition and related expenses for a taxable year. No credit is allowed for non-academic fees under subsection (a). The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified tuition and related expenses if the individual's name and taxpayer identification number are included on the tax return. The amount of expenses eligible for the credit is reduced by certain scholarships or educational assistance allowances. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified tuition and related expenses if the individual's name and taxpayer identification number are included on the tax return. The expenses eligible for the credit are reduced by scholarships or educational assistance allowances, as well as payments for educational expenses that are excludable from gross income under US law. No credit allowed for individual's taxable year beginning, qualified tuition and related expenses paid by individual treated as paid by another taxpayer. Prepayments for academic period within first 3 months after taxable year treated as beginning in that year. Double benefit denial for credit. No credit allowed for expenses with deduction, married individuals must file joint return, nonresident aliens must be treated as resident aliens for credit to apply. Inflation adjustments for dollar limitation on credit amount. Inflation adjustments for dollar limitation on credit amount: Dollar amounts under subsection (a) increased by cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 2008. Amounts rounded to nearest multiple of $100. For taxable years after 2008, dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1)(B) are increased by a cost-of-living adjustment. The adjusted amounts are rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for this section, including recapture of the credit in cases of refund in a subsequent taxable year. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by repealing section 222 on qualified tuition and related expenses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing section 222 and making various conforming amendments to sections related to tax credits and deductions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by updating various sections, such as section 529, 530, and 1400O, to reflect changes in tax credits and deductions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is updated with changes to sections 1400O, 6050S, and 6213(g)(2), including references to section 25A before the enactment date. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit applies to expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for education in academic periods starting after that date.
